PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification (ID) cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the system:
(a) is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud and, to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud;
(b) will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private nature;
(c) will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer; and
(d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended and in fact provide the opportunity for blackmail and other forms of misuse.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective and less obnoxious methods.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Assets Test: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Hawke Government's failure to correct the anomalies arising from the application of the assets test on pensioners, with the failure of the Australian Democrats to support Senator Messner's Bill to repeal the assets test, is causing unnecessary hardship for Australia's aged, particularly those living in rural areas.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Hawke Government will itself take action to repeal its iniquitous and anomalous test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving `property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals.
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: This petition of concerned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Uranium mining and processing is dangerous to the health and well-being and ecology of the Earth and its citizens.
By-products of uranium are toxic for periods of up to 500,000 years, and are an intrinsic part of the production of nuclear weapons.
Existing safeguards are inadequate, and are not properly monitored.
The policy of the Australian Government permits the entry into Australian territory of vessels and aircraft without the assurance that they are not nuclear powered or armed.
Such vessels pose a threat to both the security and well-being of Australia and its citizens.
The presence of foreign military and communication bases on Australian soil seriously endangers the health and well-being of Australia and its citizens.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable senators will take cognisance of the above and take immediate action to remove the above dangers.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Abortion Clinic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned who have great concern for the protection of the unborn child, call upon the Government to reject the Vinson enquiry recommendation that an abortion clinic be established in Canberra.
And your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will reject this recommendation.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we deplore the discriminatory tax proposals as outlined in the Government's ``White Paper'' and the Government's preferred option on proposed new and widened tax proposals as so outlined, namely:
Capital Gains Tax
Hidden Death Tax described as ``Capital Gains Tax after death''
Gift Tax
Increased Company Tax
Employer taxes on employees' employment benefits
All such taxes will discriminate against and inhibit progress, growth and employment throughout the nation.

They will attack hardworking people who have built up their assets; they will discourage thrift; they will inhibit development; they will treat unfairly all who plan for the future; they will cause trouble and expense in arriving at the value of their assets; they will discourage industry and punish achievement.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject these tax proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that Senator Grimes left on 12 October for official duties in Thailand and Europe. He will return to Australia on 3 November. —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate as Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of the constant, wrongful and unmanly attempts of the Prime Minister and Senator Button to pass the blame for the Bicentenary debacle to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and to the Australian Bicentennial Authority, I ask: Does not the Australian Bicentennial Authority Act 1980 vest in the responsible Minister-in this case, the Prime Minister-the full authority over policies and expenditures? If the Minister is in any doubt, I direct his attention to sections 6 and 11 of the Act.
—Answer that in a manly fashion. Come on now. Get a grip on yourself.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to answer it in a manly fashion. I notice that in an article in the Australian last week, Senator Chaney said that I had been given half marks for industry policy. I think I should answer it in a manly fashion in view of the continual prefect monitoring of our performance by Senator Chaney.

ANSWER.PARA: First of all, there have not been attempts by me-and I would like Senator Chaney to point to them if he can-to blame the Prime Minister's Department for any matters relating to the Bicentennial Authority. Perhaps he can refresh his memory from last Question Time, if he wants to do so on that issue.

The position regarding the Prime Minister's Department's misplacement of a letter has already been dealt with in the House of Representatives and was, of course, dealt with by a senior and respected officer of the Prime Minister's Department in a letter or minute which was sent to the Prime Minister. While the Bicentennial Authority Act vests policy responsibility in the appropriate Minister, I would point out that the question of financial responsibility as dealt with in that Act, as I recall it, goes to the questions of appropriations made in respect of the Bicentennial Authority as they are connected to policy.

I have not perused the Act recently myself, but I would remind honourable senators that in respect of the recent incident regarding the Bicentennial Authority, it was the view of the Prime Minister, his advisers and Mr Reid, the Chairman of the Authority, that the negotiations of terms and conditions of termination of employment were the responsibility of the Chairman of the Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may put a supplementary question, Mr President, is the Leader of the Government in the latter part of his answer denying that Mr Reid sought the authority of the Prime Minister under that Act for the disbursement of the moneys to Dr Armstrong?

—I do not think that question implies a correct interpretation of the facts as I see them. As I understand it, from beginning to end the appropriation of an amount to cover the settlement for Dr Armstrong was not in question. It was agreed, as I understand it, early in the discussions that the Bicentennial Authority had within its current appropriations sufficient funds to accommodate that settlement. That, as I recall it, was given in evidence to the Senate Estimates Committee. Certainly that has been stated either there or in other documents of public record. But if Senator Chaney is concerned to press the point that Mr Reid, having arrived at a settlement with Dr Armstrong, then rang the Prime Minister to inform him about it, of course that is correct. That is a matter of public record too.
—He wrote asking for authority.

—Mr Reid wrote asking for authority in terms of the final amount of the settlement on 28 August. The deed of settlement had been entered into on 23 August and signed by Mr Reid on behalf of the Bicentennial-
—Don't leave that out.

—May I answer Senator Chaney's question without Senator Walters's silly mooing? On 28 August Mr Reid wrote to the Prime Minister seeking approval for the final terms of settlement. I make the point that a deed of settlement had been entered into on 23 August, as I recall the evidence. That deed was not, of course, enclosed in the letter to the Prime Minister on the 28th and that was a matter of some disappointment.

—My question, which is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, refers to the visit to Europe by the then Tasmanian Minister for Industry and Small Business, Neil Robson, during February 1984. During a visit to the Australian Embassy in Geneva did Mr Robson give the staff a parcel which he said contained important government documents and ask them to send it through the diplomatic bag to Tasmania? Was the parcel subsequently X-rayed and impounded by Australian Customs and found to contain airline give-aways such as cakes of soap, sample shampoo sachets and disposable razors, as well as items of Mr Robson's clothing? On his return to Australia did Mr Robson receive a letter from the Department of Foreign Affairs which was severely critical of his blatant abuse of diplomatic privilege, explaining that the diplomatic bag was to be used only for sensitive and highly important documents and demanding payment of approximately $60 for the handling and freight of the parcel? Did Mr Robson then delay for some six weeks before he made the required payment to the Collector of Customs? If Mr Robson did, in fact, use the diplomatic bag for the free transport of razors, soap, underpants and hair shampoo, has the Government taken steps to ensure that there will be no repetition of the Rexona hair affair?

—The facts of this matter are as follows: Mr Robson visited the Australian Embassy in Berne and handed in a plastic container for return to Australia. He assured the officer in Berne that it contained documentary material relating to an European Management Forum symposium he had attended at Davos. The parcel was not X-rayed. However, it was inspected and impounded by Australian Customs. It was found to contain sample toiletries, toys and socks. On 2 May 1984 a letter was sent to Mr Robson advising him that costs amounting to $60.37 had been incurred in returning the case from Berne to Tasmania and he was requested to reimburse the Department of Foreign Affairs this amount. On 24 July 1984 Mr Robson's executive officer forwarded the Minister's cheque to the Department. Strict instructions have been forwarded to all overseas posts specifying that only official items can be forwarded in the diplomatic bag. Any items of a personal nature must be forwarded by commercial means at the explicit cost of the consignee.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of the constant wrongful and unmanly attempts of the Prime Minister and Senator Button to pass the blame for the Bicentennial debacle to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and to the Australian Bicentennial Authority, I ask: Is it not the full responsibility of the Government to scrutinise, modify or reject all estimates of proposed expenditure submitted by the Authority and to determine the appropriations for each financial year? If this is so, are not the Government and particularly the responsible Minister-in this case, Mr Hawke-wholly responsible for any alleged extravagances or wastefulness in the Authority?

—The cabal that has been meeting in a Senate meeting room determining not only the contents of the question but also its language-`this wrongful and unmanly attempt by the Prime Minister and Senator Button'--
—Quite right. How would you describe it, right and manly?
—Order! Senator Chaney, you have asked a question and a supplementary question. I ask you to let Senator Button make a reply.

—There is some advantage, I would have thought, even with this Opposition having some elegance in the language it uses. The repetition of banal phrases will not get it very far, I would not think. Be that as it may, of course it is the responsibility of the Parliament to approve the estimates for any department or authority of the Government on each appropriate occasion. It is the responsibility of each Minister to scrutinise the overall level of expenditure. As I have already answered Senator Chaney, the question of approving the appropriation did not arise in the immediate context in which the recent matter of the Bicentennial payment to Dr Armstrong was approved, as I understand it. I think that is a matter of record. If Senator Messner reads the answer to the question asked by Senator Chaney he will find out the answer to his own question as well.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Notwithstanding Senator Button's answer, he must acknowledge that the Prime Minister is responsible for the general approval of the estimates for the Bicentennial Authority.
—Of course any Minister is responsible for the whole program in respect of any authority which he administers. That has not been denied by anybody.

—Can the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs confirm media reports that 12 Irian Jayan refugees were forcibly repatriated from Papua New Guinea in the past few days? If so, can the Government ascertain the reasons for this repatriation? In view of the reports of ill-treatment of refugees by Indonesian authorities, will the Government be taking any steps to ensure that refugees will not be repatriated against their will?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has noted the return of 12 Irianese to the Indonesian province of Irian Jaya by the Government of Papua New Guinea. At this stage the Government does not have full details relating to this return but media reports have stated that the 12 were gaoled on their return. I understand that the Indonesian Government's policy is that Irianese border crossers who have broken Indonesian laws will be tried on their return to Irian Jaya. The Government is seeking further information on the circumstances surrounding the return of the 12 and their subsequent treatment.

ANSWER.PARA: All I can perhaps usefully add is that the Government remains concerned at any suggestion of discrimination against the Melanesian population of Irian Jaya and has indicated to the Indonesian authorities its belief that Melanesian aspirations and cultural values should be accommodated within the framework of Indonesia's national development. We have also indicated our hope that the transmigration program in Irian Jaya will be conducted in such a way as to avoid any adverse effects for Irian Jaya's Melanesian population.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. Is the proposed boundary of the northern section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park on the zoning plan now before the Parliament to the east of the boundary originally proposed in 1983? Was the boundary moved to the east solely to accommodate the interests of a mining company which wishes to build a jetty and export mineral sands to Japan from a point nearby? Is the alteration to the proposed boundary of the northern section an indication of a willingness on the part of the Government to restrict the area of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park in order to accommodate the interests of mining companies and the Queensland Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of Senator Chipp's question is no. The boundary of the far north section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park is as it was proclaimed on 31 August 1983. The answer to the second part of his question is also no. However, in the far northern section draft zoning plan, released for public comment in April 1984, Shelburne Bay was zoned marine national park `B' in order to protect its sea-grass beds which are prime dugong habitat. As a result of submissions received during the public review period a small area has been changed to less restrictive general use `A' zoning. In the view of Dr Helene Marsh, a recognised expert on dugong, this small area is neither primary nor secondary dugong habitat.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to Senator Chipp's third question is also no. In accordance with requirements under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, public representations on the draft zoning plan for the far northern section of the marine park were invited during April-July 1984. One hundred and seventy-seven representations were received and the zoning plan was revised, where appropriate, to take the representations into account.

I should make it clear to the Senate and to the people of Australia, and particularly to those in the conservation movement, that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is not ignoring advice from anyone in relation to the marine park, particularly advice from experts. Moreover, I am advised that the Authority does not cave in to pressure from developmental interests when those interests are inimical to the object of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and the objectives of the Authority, which are to ensure that reasonable use of the marine park is provided for consistent with conservation of the Great Barrier Reef. Honourable senators should be aware that the balancing of these two considerations is the essence of the zoning procedures which, incidentally, is the essence of the national conservation strategy and the world conservation strategy. I am further advised that this sometimes means that activities are permitted in the marine park which some people think should not be allowed. Conversely, it also means that activities which are considered reasonable by some people are not permitted.

Honourable senators should also appreciate that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is, as a matter of law, only able to take into account considerations which are relevant to the marine park in making zoning and other decisions. The effects of any jetty or shipping movements on the marine park would clearly be relevant and would be taken into account before any decision was made to permit those activities. On the other hand, a development on an area outside the marine park which does not affect the marine park could not be taken into account by the Authority in decision making.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. Mr President, you have said repeatedly that answers to questions should be short. It seems to me that the Minister is making a ministerial statement. I believe that she should not present her reply in this way.

—Order! There is no point of order. It is my understanding that the Minister is responding to the points raised by Senator Chipp in his question. At this stage certainly she is not debating the matter. I call the Minister.

—Mr President, just before I was interrupted by Senator Jessop I had concluded the answer. I think Senator Chipp's question is of general interest to the Senate and to the Australian public. I was pleased, on behalf of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, to give Senator Chipp the information which he sought. I will undertake to do so again should Senator Chipp seek further information on this very important matter of national significance.

—My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Further to my question on domiciliary nursing services on 12 September 1985, the Minister should be aware of statements made by the honourable member for Franklin, Mr Goodluck, and others, contained in various Tasmanian newspapers over the weekend and this morning, to the effect that veterans will be disadvantaged by the new domiciliary nursing arrangements being negotiated with the Tasmanian Government. Would the Minister outline current developments and repeat assurances to veterans that they will not be disadvantaged by any new arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall Senator Devlin asking a question about changes that are taking place in respect of domiciliary nursing in Tasmania. I indicated at that time my preference for negotiations to be entered into with the Tasmanian Government. Any notion, therefore, that veterans in Tasmania will be disadvantaged by the new arrangements, as stated by Mr Goodluck, is very distressful to veterans. I regard it as baseless, contemptible and illogical because the purpose of the negotiations was in fact to meet the wishes of the Tasmanian Government and its Minister, Mr Cleary. In fact, such agreement has been reached, literally on every point. I only hope that the Liberal Party can get its act together. In the interests of goodwill between the two governments, I have responded to negotiations and requests made by the Tasmanian Minister for Health, and those negotiations have been very fruitful. They have been designed to maintain the highest standard of nursing of aged veterans in Tasmania and, of course, they are in accordance with negotiations taking place in all States of the Commonwealth. A degree of consensus has been reached at both officer and ministerial level. That is a matter of great achievement, and not one which deserves the inflammatory and distressful remarks made by Mr Goodluck.

ANSWER.PARA: I stress again the changes I referred to previously. The efficiency audit, carried out by my Department, concluded that the cost to my Department of domiciliary services was considerably higher in Tasmania than the national standard, and, consequently, we had an obligation to find out the reason why. The only point of contention that still remains to be concluded, is the matter of the employment of those nurses employed under the old scheme in a way which will give security of tenure, workers compensation, superannuation benefits and so on. I have an undertaking from the Tasmanian Minister that those problems will be ironed out to the satisfaction of the nurses currently employed. There is no question that the existing nurses have carried out a satisfactory service over the years, but the costs of that service exceeded the national average and we were therefore entitled to improve the costing aspect of it. I am somewhat astounded that Tasmanian Liberals would suggest that we are traversing new ground and acting in a way detrimental to the welfare of veterans. I repeat what I said on a previous occasion. We have a preference to enter into arrangements with the State governments in respect of such matters, and those arrangements have been concluded very satisfactorily with the Tasmanian Minister for Health.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's refusal to accept any ministerial responsibility for the Australian Bicentennial Authority debacle. When the Prime Minister assumed responsibility for the Authority in December 1984, and thereby took over from Mr Cohen more than 800 files relating to the Authority, its policies and expenditure, did he order that a study be made of those files and that a report be presented to him of their broad nature and any deficiencies? If so, what was the nature of the report and what action did the Prime Minister take on it?

—I would like to congratulate Senator Short on his intellectual deftness by deleting the words `wrongly' and `unmanly' from his question, wherever they might appear. As Senator Short knows, the 800 files were taken over by the Prime Minister's Department from the Department of Home Affairs and Environment in December 1984 and January 1985. I am unaware of whether the Prime Minister ordered a study, in terms of Senator Short's question, which produced a report. I will seek that information. It seems to me most unlikely that the Prime Minister ordered a study, and it is most unlikely that when any files are taken over from one department to another the responsible Minister in this Government, or in any government, orders a study, as Senator Short puts it. But I will find out about the particular circumstances and provide an answer as soon as possible.

—I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer, but would he not agree that the ordering of such a study and report would simply constitute a normal and essential exercise of ministerial responsibility?

—No, I would not agree with that. I regard it as a responsibility which may from time to time be assumed in any transfer by officers of the Australian Public Service, but I would not regard it as an absolute necessity. I am sure that plenty of former Ministers sitting opposite would be fully aware of that circumstance.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate as Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of the attempts of the Prime Minister and Senator Button to pass the blame for the Bicentennial debacle to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Australian Bicentennial Authority, I ask: Since December 1984, when the Prime Minister assumed responsibility for the Authority, has there been in existence in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet a special secretariat responsible to the Prime Minister for the functioning of the Authority? How many changes have been made in the secretariat during the lifetime of the Hawke Government? When was the last change made? Was it extensive? How long before 15 August, the date the Prime Minister ordered the termination of Dr Armstrong's services, was the last change made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brownhill has rephrased his question with the customary deftness that we have come to expect from him, following the example of Senator Short. Since December 1984 a branch of the Prime Minister's Department relating to the Bicentennial matters has been in existence. Senator Brownhill asks how many changes there have been in the lifetime of the Hawke Government in Public Service administration or liaison with the Bicentennial Authority. As I recall, the Bicentennial Authority began its life under the wing of the Department of Administrative Services. It then went to the Department of Home Affairs and the Environment and, subsequently, in December 1984 it went to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Brownhill also asked how long before 15 August 1985 were changes made in the appropriate division or branch of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in relation to the Bicentennial Authority. I am unable to say because I am not quite sure what the honourable senator means by that question. I am sure that there have been changes of personnel and so on. The only major changes which have taken place have been those recently announced by the Prime Minister, whereby the section has been brought up to its full strength of 15 personnel. Prior to that I think that there were no major changes. But I will have that checked out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women seen comments in the Hobart Mercury from an opponent of this Government once again misrepresenting the Government's affirmative action proposals? Will the Minister therefore restate whether the proposed legislation strikes at the heart of the principle of recruitment and promotion on the basis of merit, as suggested? Does the legislation represent the first step in the direction of quotas, despite the Government's clear statement to the contrary?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how often mischievous people are going to misrepresent the facts about the Government's affirmative action policy, and I do not know how long media outlets will be prepared to promote these totally misleading ideas. The whole point of the Government's approach to affirmative action in private sector employment is to establish a situation in which women may be judged on their merits. If Mrs Holmes would care to address herself to the progress report put out by the Office of the Status of Women Affirmative Action Resource Unit, which reported in some detail on the affirmative action pilot program, she would gain an understanding of what our Government means by affirmative action for women in employment in the private sector.

ANSWER.PARA: What it means, very briefly, is this: Under our approach to affirmative action, large employers in the private sector will undertake a systematic review and analysis of their recruitment, employment, promotion and training policies to ensure that women are not being excluded from opportunities in training and employment on criteria other than merit, for example, that they are not being denied the opportunity for technical or managerial training on an assumption that they may leave the employment to have children, that they have children and their children may get sick making them unable to fulfil their terms of employment, or any other criteria of these kinds which are not applied to men in a similar circumstance.

I remind the Senate, and Senator Coates will perhaps remind Mrs Holmes, that the working party brought down a consensus report on this matter. The reason why there has been such general support, and even enthusiasm, for the Government's approach to affirmative action on the part of the Business Council of Australia and the Confederation of Australian Industry is that they appreciate that it is in the interests of an employer to recruit and promote on merit. They appreciate the fact that our approach will mean that the pool of eligible talent for any particular position will be much larger if women can get into that pool. Once in the pool, of course, they will be assessed on their capacity to do the job, as men have been, and the best person will get the job. In many cases the best person will continue to be a male person. Now under the new arrangements, the best person will turn out to be a woman much more often than in the past when there was structural discrimination against women.

Those of us who are concerned that people should get jobs on their merits should recognise that the whole purpose of our approach to affirmative action is to develop a situation in private employment, as we are already doing in the public sector, whereby, in regard to acceptance to train as an apprentice, acceptance for employment with promotion possibilities or acceptance for on the job training in blue collar, white collar or managerial areas, women will not be discounted simply because they are women, because they are married or because they have children, but their particular capacities to do the job will be assessed and the decision will be made on merit. I would be very grateful if Senator Coates passed that information on to Mrs Holmes and to the Mercury. This has been clearly the Government's intention from the outset, and it really is rather discouraging to find people who ought to know better persisting in misrepresenting the objectives of the Government's approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw attention to the presence in the Presidential Gallery of former Senator Gordon Davidson from South Australia. On behalf of all honourable senators I extend to him a warm and friendly welcome upon his return to Canberra.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of the constant, wrongful and unpersonable attempts of the Prime Minister and Senator Button to pass the blame for the Bicentennial debacle to the Prime Minister's Department and to the Australian Bicentennial Authority, I ask: Did the Prime Minister during the period between his instruction on 15 August to terminate Dr Armstrong's services and the final settlement on 30 August seek the advice of the Solicitor-General or any other law officers or accountant? If so, when and whom? Did the Prime Minister seek any advice from his Department before 28 August as to the terms of severance of Dr Armstrong's employment or ask for a copy of the terms of Dr Armstrong's employment, which were in his Department at all relevant times? If so, when, and what was the advice he received?

—Having regard to Senator Baume's past career as a publicist of some note, I would have thought that the word `unpersonable' would not help very much. It is not a word that journalists will pick up. It is not a very euphonic sort of expression. Perhaps the honourable senator should try something else. In respect of each of the questions asked by Senator Baume, those questions have been answered by the Prime Minister in the House of Representatives and are a matter of record in the House of Representatives Hansard.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. Have decisions been made by the Minister and the Western Australian Government in relation to the development of the Old Leighton Battery site which overlooks Fremantle and which is presently owned by the Commonwealth? To whom will the site be sold, for what price and what is the intended use after sale?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Negotiations by the Federal Government have been proceeding for some time with the Western Australian Government and agreement has been reached that a decision in relation to the Old Leighton Battery site will be concluded in a very short period. The site, I understand, is situated on Buckland Hill overlooking Fremantle. The Australian Government has reached agreement with the Western Australian Government that the site should be developed to provide a mix of recreational parkland facilities and public and private housing; thus the future use of the site will be for the benefit of the people of Western Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The site has a potential value of $9.5m. I think the Australian Government has indicated to the Western Australian Premier that it is considering a price which is not less than half that amount in respect of the actual purchase price by the Western Australian Government. The State, in negotiations, has nominated the Western Australian Development Corporation to oversee the development. That Corporation has agreed that the price that it will recommend to the Western Australian Government will reflect the market value on the proposed mix that I have referred to. Consequently, the process is such that very shortly agreement will be reached. As I indicated in answer to a question last week, the Government is trying to expedite negotiations with the States in regard to the sale of a number of Commonwealth properties. I refer to Tasman Island in Tasmania, the arrangements in respect of foreshore land on Sydney Harbour and this site in Western Australia. We are confident that agreement will be reached within the next few weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Is it a fact that the Prime Minister has recently trebled the actual number of public servants in the section of his Department dealing with the Australian Bicentennial Authority? Will extra staff be recruited to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to handle the work previously done by the transferred officers? What will be the cost to the taxpayers of this action of the Prime Minister, which is the latest of his efforts to escape personal responsibility for his gross mishandling of the Bicentennial fiasco?

—As I understand it, the Prime Minister is seeking roughly a doubling of the staff resources allocated to the ABA. I received-I am not sure whether it was last Thursday or Friday-a letter from the Prime Minister which referred not only to the proposed numbers but also the staff profile that he was proposing for the ABA. It has been transferred to the Secretary of the Department of Finance and I expect it to be dealt with probably before the end of this week.
—I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister answer the final part of the question: What will be the cost if the request is acceded to?
—At this stage I cannot answer that.

—Can the Minister for Fin- ance advise the Senate of the results of the Government's review of the so-called loan back arrangements made by the previous Government under which Telecom Australia was allowed to retain part of its annual employer superannuation contributions to the Commonwealth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Telecom was first established in 1975 the funds for its capital expenditure were provided in the Budget. At some later time, if I recall correctly, there was a mixture for capital funding of internally generated funds, Budget funds and funds borrowed. The borrowed funds, whether they came from the Budget appropriation or not of course would be counted directly or indirectly in the public sector borrowing requirement. Telecom, along with a number of other statutory authorities, has also paid annually to the Commonwealth a contribution to cover the superannuation liabilities of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme which is responsible for Telecom employees. Those payments by Telecom are regarded as financial transactions and do not therefore affect the Budget deficit. I expect to be making a comprehensive statement before very long on not only Telecom's superannuation arrangements but also those of other statutory authorities.

ANSWER.PARA: However, in 1978 when Mr Howard was presenting his first Budget, he resorted to fiscal chicanery to achieve a cosmetic reduction in both government spending and the deficit. The practice that he adopted then continued until 1982. The practice he adopted was to loan back notionally to Telecom the contributions it had paid into the Commonwealth superannuation scheme to cover the liability. The loan backs were interest free loans which had no contractual basis, for which there was no formal repayment obligation and which were never authorised by Parliament. The purpose and effect of that prime example of shonky accountancy was to conceal the true size of the deficit and the public sector borrowing requirement. By the time Mr Howard was removed from office during the 1982-83 financial year, he had deceitfully concealed in total some $500m of what should have showed as both the deficit--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Use of the word `deceitful' in relation to an honourable member in another place is quite unparliamentary.
—Order! I must admit that my attention was diverted for one moment. If the Minister used that expression in relation to an honourable member in another place I ask him to withdraw it.
—If that is regarded by you as unparliamentary, of course I withdraw it, Mr President. Perhaps I could say that he unmanfully concealed--
—And wrongfully.
—He wrongfully concealed in aggregate $500m which ought to have appeared in the deficit and on outlays, in the public sector borrowing requirement or a mixture of both.

ANSWER.PARA: That was the situation which this Government inherited. In the 1983 Budget the arrangement was formalised by the present Government and Telecom was required to pay interest on that so-called loan back arrangement. In 1984 further loans were discontinued and repayments of the loans advanced during the Howard period as Treasurer have commenced. As I said earlier, I expect to make a more comprehensive statement on this matter, certainly before the Parliament resumes, in which, in a more formal way, I will expose the fiscal chicanery to which the discredited former Treasurer resorted in order to distort, conceal and misrepresent the true level of Commonwealth outlays, the deficit and the public sector borrowing requirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. For the same reasons as were given before, I seek to have the word `chicanery' and the other words withdrawn, particularly in view of the fact that, as Senator Walsh well knows, evidence in relation to that was given to a committee of which he was a member at a public hearing before his Party took over government.
—Order! I think that the use of the word `chicanery' does impute dishonesty on the part of a member of the Parliament. Therefore, I ask the Minister to withdraw the expression.
—If that is your wish, Mr President, of course I withdraw.
—It is my wish.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance both in his own capacity and as Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to a statement made by the Treasurer when he introduced the tax package. The Treasurer said:

QUESTION.PARA: An independent inquiry has been established to examine the impact of the White Paper proposal on the gold mining industry.
In the Senate last week, on 9 October, in a pitiful attempt to answer a question I put to Senator Walsh, he said:
The fact, as Senator Durack knows very well, is that the Government has set up a study regarding the taxing of gold or the future taxation status of gold mining.
I might say that I am not aware of that study having been set up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Will the honourable senator ask his question.
—I ask the Minister: Has the committee been established? If so, when was it established? Who are the members of it? Has it met? What are the terms of reference?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am astounded that Senator Durack should see fit to raise this question again. There can be only one possible reason for raising it, because Senator Durack knows the facts very well. He has raised it because he believes the discredited Liberal Party of Western Australia might be able to get a bit of political mileage out of this issue. They are common tactics, but what I find astounding is that the present leader of the Liberal Party is reported in the Kalgoorlie Miner of 6 August this year as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Speaking at a Minerals and Energy Club of Australia luncheon in Brisbane, Mr Howard said that he doubted if gold could retain its privileged tax-free status for very much longer.
Senator Chaney, writing in the Australian on 17 February 1984, said:
Since gold no longer has any particular monetary significance it is a commodity like any other, its price being determined by the market.
Neither the magic and mythology of its history nor economic logic justify the special treatment of gold.
I would have thought that those quotations established very clearly that the Liberal Party has every intention of ending the tax-free status of gold.

When the former Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, was bailed up in Perth four days after Mr Howard made his statement signalling that the Opposition, if it ever returned to government, would tax gold-in response to remarks by the Federal Opposition spokesman on Treasury matters who was reported to have said that he would not guarantee that a future Liberal government would not tax gold-Mr Peacock said that he would guarantee that a Liberal government would not tax gold. Since then we all know that Mr Peacock has been deposed as Liberal Party Leader and has been replaced by Mr Howard. Therefore, one would assume that Mr Howard's assurances are not the same as Mr Peacock's.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The Minister has not yet touched upon the matter which was raised in the question, which was the question of whether the Government has established a committee, which it undertook to do when it brought down its statement. He is simply debating the question and I believe you should call him to order, Mr President.
—I ask the Minister to respond to the question.

—Certainly, Mr President. It is not my fault if mugs on the Opposition front bench insist on leading with their chin. The fact, as Senator Durack knows very well-it is set out quite clearly in the Treasurer's statement of 19 September-is that the Government has decided not to adopt the White Paper proposal on the taxing of gold. The Treasurer said that an independent inquiry had been established to examine the impact of the taxation question on the gold industry and that it was expected to report in the first half of 1986. I do not know whether a meeting has been held. I will inquire of the Treasurer and let Senator Durack know.
—If I may ask a supplementary question, the Minister has indulged in the greatest bit of obfuscation-
—Order! Will the honourable senator ask his supplementary question?

—On a point of order, Mr President: It seems to be open to have endless obfuscation in answers in this place and a small preliminary comment in a question is objected to. I would ask for some evenhandedness in this matter.

—Order! Question Time is limited to an hour. There have been five supplementary questions to date, and I do not deny anyone the right to ask supplementary questions, but if we allow supplementary questions to become supplementary statements, the matter gets completely out of hand. I have asked endlessly for honourable senators to keep their questions as short as possible, and I have also asked Ministers to respond as expeditiously and as briefly as possible. I ask everyone to adopt those rules and then everyone will get a fair go.

—I asked the Minister four questions. He has answered only one of them-and in fact he has not answered that. I asked when was the committee established, who are the members of it, has it met and what are its terms of reference.
—I can only repeat the answer I gave before. I will inquire of the Treasurer and let Senator Durack know.

—My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Has the Government given priority in implementation of the affirmative action policy to the advanced education sector? If so, what is the reason for this, and what progress has been made so far towards this goal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes; the phasing in arrangements decided on by the Government on affirmative action will involve coverage of the higher education institutions first-that is, we expect to have the legislation passed early next year and higher education institutions will be covered from then. In the next year the coverage will extend to corporations that employ more than 1,000 employees, after that to corporations that employ more than 500 employees, and then, last, to corporations that employ more than 100 employees. The reason for starting with higher education institutions is fundamentally a practical one. Many higher education institutions already have affirmative action programs under way. All institutions in New South Wales are already covered by the New South Wales legislation, although it is the view of representatives of higher education that we should seek to have them covered by Federal legislation when it is enacted. But certainly that will be facilitated by the fact that all institutions in New South Wales are already required to develop affirmative action programs.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the case that many other higher education institutions have voluntarily started to develop affirmative action. The processes are well under way and the job for the Government to set up a government monitoring agency and a form of communication with the participants in the program will be easier. It is also a fact that higher education has a very bad record when it comes to equal employment opportunities for women. If one makes a gender analysis of employment in higher education, the results will show that in many cases higher education institutions seem to have worse structural discrimination against women than some corporations, so the need is certainly there to act. There is also unanimous support from unions covering staff in higher education institutions and their co-operation is assured. We believe that the program will be most successfully implemented by starting with those organisations, many of which are already preparing to do this, and where there is widespread support.

Great support was given to the Government's affirmative action pilot program by representatives of both higher education sectors. Professor Michael Birt, Vice-Chancellor of the University of New South Wales and current Chairman of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, and Dr Graham Swain, the representative of the Australian College of Directors and Principals Association, were extremely constructive and gave a great deal of assistance to the work of the working party. So we believe that, in starting with higher education, our policy will be falling on fertile fields.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Has the Minister seen the text of a major address given by Mr Duffy to the Public Conference on the Future of Australian Commercial Television on 30 September 1985? I ask whether, in that address, Mr Duffy stated:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the Government supports networking. We not only accept the ABT observation that `networks and networking are the heart and arteries of the commercial TV system', but we wish to do everything possible to encourage broadcasters to utilise satellite networking techniques . . .

I note that the word `encourage' is underlined in the Minister's text. Does the Minister accept that this policy is fundamentally incompatible with any policy of localism? Is the Government now formally abandoning the principles laid down in the Oswin inquiry and its own previous commitment to support of localism in commercial broadcasting?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked whether I have read Mr Duffy's speech of 30 September, and the answer is no, although I am sure that it was a very good speech. As I have not read it, I am not able either to confirm or to refute what Senator Puplick has said or the meaning he has ascribed to it. I will refer that to Mr Duffy for an answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a speech by the former Secretary to the Treasury, Mr John Stone, to the Mont Pelerin Society in which he asserted that the Commonwealth Public Service Board has been politicised under the Hawke Government? Can the Minister explain the facts of this matter and how Mr Stone's assertion fits with those facts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention has been drawn to the speech in question. In fact, I read the speech in question some weeks ago. In that speech Mr Stone asserted, among other things, that the Public Service Board, and I think one could say the Public Service in general, was politicised by this Labor Government and that some of those public servants who did the Labor Party's political dirty work were rewarded with extraordinary promotions. In support of that assertion he referred to the promotion of a division head to Public Service Board commissioner. In the speech he said:

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot recall any previous examples of mere Division Heads, even from very senior Departments such as the Treasury or Prime Minister and Cabinet, ever before having been elevated overnight to the standing of Public Service Commissioner (which ranks equivalent to the lesser Departmental Heads in the Canberra hierarchical pecking order).

In fact, the previous appointment prior to the appointment to which Mr Stone referred-that being the appointment of Mr Taylor-was an appointment of a mere division head, as Mr Stone put it, and he was promoted to Public Service Board commissioner. Moreover, since 1970 a total of 12 public servants of level 4 status or below-that is, mere division heads-have been appointed as secretaries to departments or the rank equivalent to secretaries to departments. In view of that, I find it rather ironic that Mr Stone should have written a letter to the editor of the West Australian of 5 October in which, among other things, he said:
I am accustomed to politicians not only getting things wrong, but getting them wrong with some political purpose in mind.

Therefore, when that letter and the Mont Pelerin address are looked at simultaneously, it can be seen that Mr Stone certainly got things wrong. Indeed, he backed up his central hypothesis with an assertion which was not only baseless but which he, as a former senior public servant, should also have known was baseless. One can only speculate on whether he did that, to use his words again, with some political purpose in mind. I invite him in his next diatribe to clarify whether he misstated the truth for political purposes or whether he was culpably ignorant. I say `culpably ignorant' because for a person in Mr Stone's position to be unaware of the facts I have outlined is, in my view, culpable. I suppose there is a third sad alternative and that is that cerebral deterioration has reached the point where Mr Stone should no longer be held responsible for his actions, which would give credence to recent rumours that he is about to become a National Party parliamentary candidate in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. In the light of the confusion from apparently conflicting statements from the Government in relation to visits by United States Navy warships, will the Minister give a categorical assurance that no request has been made to the United States Government to restrict the number of its ship visits to this country? Have restrictions of any sort been placed on rest and recreation visits by the USN to Western Australian ports?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Defence whose responsibility it is.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Sanders-Mr President, I raise a point of order under standing order 998, which states:

After Notices have been given Questions may be put to Ministers of the Crown relating to public affairs; and to other Senators, relating to any Bill, Motion or other public matter connected with the business on the Notice Paper, of which such Senators may have charge.

Over and over again Question Time has been misused by honourable senators on both sides of the chamber and senators who have real questions to ask have not been given the time to ask them. I am sure that certain Ministers would like to have time to answer them. I ask that standing order 98 be adhered to. We, as members of this Parliament and representatives of the people, are being denied our rights to seek information from Ministers of the Crown.

Senator Chaney-Mr President, I want to speak on the point of order because there has been some concern among Opposition senators about the asking of questions. On the figures which have been taken out it is quite clear that the Australian Democrats, including the honourable member who has just risen, have certainly had more than their proportional share of questions in this place. I do not object to that. I simply say that that is the way the numbers are running at present. I ask that in considering the point of order you consider whether there are some ways by which the excessive debating of questions could be terminated. I think that is a very significant problem in this place. I do not believe that there is a problem with respect to your allocation of questions among the parties.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order. Senator Sanders has raised the general question of the conduct of Question Time. I have pointed out over and over again that it is possible for the Chair to have only a certain control over the length of questions and the type of comment contained in them. The Chair has only a certain amount of control over the way in which Ministers choose to answer questions. How questions are asked is a matter for the person asking the questions; how questions are answered is a matter for the Ministers answering them. Over and over again I have appealed to honourable senators asking questions and to Ministers answering them to keep their questions and answers as brief and to the point as possible so that everyone can get a fair go.

INTERJECT.PARA: I have tried to keep the balance of questions between the Opposition and members of the Australian Democrats, in proportion. I think I have done so fairly, on balance. From time to time it gets out of equilibrium. Today I tried to balance it. It will be noted and observed that the Democrats asked only one question today. Probably they will ask two questions tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Lest it be thought that members on this side of the chamber accept the description of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as being `wrongful and unmanly' in certain aspects of his conduct of office, I ask you, Mr President, to give consideration to circulating a letter to members of the Senate drawing attention to standing order 99 which prevents questions containing arguments, inferences, imputations or epithets and wed it to standing order 418 which speaks of highly disorderly conduct in casting personal reflections on members of another place. Also, it is quite wrongful to build into the opening gambit of a question descriptions of members of another place which are, as I say, highly disorderly and amount to an argument about the character of the Minister concerned which may well be a conclusion to flow from the answer but should not be put in the question.

—Order! I draw Senator Tate's attention to the fact that on the back of the sheets on which questions without notice can be written there are examples of the types of expressions that should or should not be used. I must say, though, that I have been concerned for some time at the type of looseness of speech or innuendo that might be involved both in some of the questions that are asked and in some of the answers that are given. It is my intention, hopefully this week, to have a discussion with the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the Leader of the Opposition and Senator Chipp about the general manner in which some of the innuendoes are being thrown around this chamber. I hope that this practice can cease.
—Mr President, I seek leave to make a short statement.
—Is leave granted?
—No.
—Leave is not granted.

—During Question Time Senator Jones asked me a question about reports of journalists and others going to South Africa for the Hughes rebel cricket tour. I now have in front of me the brief relevant to that question. My attention has been drawn to those reports that a number of Australians and sports writers will be in South Africa to follow the Australian rebel cricket tour. The Government's policies on sporting contacts with South Africa are well known and have been publicly stated on too many occasions recently to need repetition now. The Australian code of business conduct, which is still in draft form and has not yet come into operation, is concerned with the operation of Australian companies having commercial or other interests in South Africa. So the accreditation of Australian journalists to cover events in South Africa would not appear to be relevant to the operations of that code of conduct.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Peter Baume proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Federal Labor Government, in common with the New South Wales Labor Government, to provide adequate emergency relief for the poor.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my State of New South Wales is in the midst of a welfare crisis of the most severe proportions. That is the reason we are asking the Senate today to debate this matter of public importance in the terms which you have just read out.
—Not because Senator Grimes is away!

—I am interested that the Labor Whip seeks to interject at this stage. Maybe he does not care about the crisis which is occurring in my State and which I am now going to set out. The Sydney Morning Herald of Saturday 12 October contained a front page story by a very senior reporter, Mr Graham Williams, which identified the dimensions of the crisis we face. The story, which appeared under the chilling headline `NSW 1985: soup-kitchens reject the hungry', commenced as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Thirty hungry people were refused a meal at the big soup-kitchen run by the Hare Krishna community at Darlinghurst on Wednesday when it ran out of food-rice, mung beans and spiced vegetables-for the first time in five years, after record queues of poor people arrived to be fed.

And not far away, the Smith Family central office at Darlinghurst had to close its doors two hours early on Tuesday and Wednesday, for the first time turning away scores of people seeking urgent assistance.

Most of these people had previously been rejected by the NSW Government welfare officers in the crackdown on emergency relief which has resulted from the wrangle between State and Federal governments over who is responsible for the payments.

That sets out some of the dimensions of the crisis. The facts of the matter do not seem to be in dispute. It seems that there genuinely is a crisis. It seems that the flow of emergency funds genuinely has dried up. It seems that the Hare Krishnas have had vastly increased numbers just seeking some food and that the Smith Family has had unprecedented calls. Other voluntary agencies across my State to which those in dire need have had to turn are also running out of resources. This is genuinely a matter of public importance; it is genuinely a matter which warrants discussion by the Senate, for the problem rests with the macho Ministers in two Labor governments who cannot get their acts together and who are using the poor as pawns and hostages. It needs fixing. Why have the numbers catered for by the voluntary agencies increased by over 50 per cent in recent weeks? Why have they increased so much, particularly since 1 October? This is a matter of genuine public importance. In the Sydney Morning Herald of last Saturday, the General Secretary of the Smith Family, Mr Bob Turner, said:
The situation is now desperate and it will get worse, much worse.
At the Hare Krishna kitchen, Siddartha Das said:
We had ten days of very big queues before we ran out of food. We just didn't expect such huge numbers.
The article went on:
A check by the Herald shows that a crisis of need is building up throughout Sydney since the State Government--
that is, the Labor Government in New South Wales-
stopped its $6.8m a year emergency assistance to the needy on October 1.

Can you believe it? The State Labor Government has stopped its emergency assistance to the needy, and this has brought on the crisis. It has come about because of a callous power play between two Labor governments-one in New South Wales and one in Canberra-over who is responsible. It is almost unbelievable to see two Labor governments brawling, with the poorest in society as the hostages in the game. It is this conflict between Ministers at each level-both probably on salaries of more than $80,000-with the needy as their hostages which is so immoral and which needs relief now. I am attracted to today's Sydney Morning Herald which has as its cartoon a very unedifying picture of a Labor Minister in New South Wales, Mr Walker, and a Labor Minister in Canberra, Senator Grimes, arm wrestling, with the poor caught in their fists, while on the wall is an old quotation, which some will know is to be found on the Statue of Liberty: `Give me your poor, your helpless.' Give the poor and helpless to them! In New South Wales they will go hungry and they will go without because these governments have not got their acts together. This kind of conflict is exposing the needy to starvation and deprivation. The fact is that the New South Wales Government, in its recent Budget, reduced its spending on emergency relief in the welfare area from something over $8m a year to just over $5m. This was the first step in its decision to phase out completely emergency relief to most of the needy.

Each side-the State Labor Government and the Commonwealth Labor Government-says that the other one should bear the responsibility. That in itself can be determined in the fullness of time. Someone needs to undertake the responsibility. I do not wish to enter that argument. I wish only to examine what they are saying, perhaps to examine what Senator Grimes has said, to come back to the plight of the needy, which is so dramatically before those of us who represent New South Wales, and to ask that something be done. I say with vehemence that I do not want to enter the agrument about who should pay; let the Ministers work that one out.
We know that on one side Mr Frank Walker, the New South Wales Labor Minister, says that emergency assistance is a responsibility of the Federal Government. He said:
All the people who need emergency funds are already recipients of Commonwealth benefits-this simply goes to show that Commonwealth benefits are inadequate.

The only editorial comment that I would add is that if that is his justification for making it a Federal responsibility he had better go back to law school and study some more logic. Perhaps he has also forgotten the mutual contribution and responsibility of the Commonwealth and the States; and perhaps he has forgotten particularly the contribution of the Labor Government in New South Wales to bringing on this crisis.

My colleague Senator Puplick later will draw more attention to the role of the New South Wales Government, by the charges that it has imposed on the poorest in New South Wales, in bringing on this crisis. We know that Mr Walker's view is shared in other parts of Australia. Mrs Toner, the former Victorian Minister for Community Welfare Services, is on record as saying:

One of the main platforms of the Labor Government was to get the Federal Government to assume its responsibilities on income security. The voluntary agencies and the State Government are continually having to top up the deficiencies caused by inadequate Federal benefits.

Again, that is an oversimplistic analysis by a Labor Minister. There is no doubt where she and Mr Walker stand. But they are not alone in this view. Senator Grimes, before he became Minister for Social Security and now Minister for Community Services, was the Opposition spokesman in this area. In April 1982, while in Opposition, Senator Grimes had no doubt about where things stood. We were then the Federal Government and he said about us:

The Federal Government must take responsibility for its dependants who cannot survive on the benefits they are paid. This means that payments should be raised to a reasonable level so that people do not have to do without.
I quote Senator Grimes further:

Along with a rise in payments, especially for those in greatest need, we believe that the Federal Government will have to take a greater responsibility in providing for the additional needs of people whose income cannot cover their necessary expenses, particularly those dependent on government.

There we have the views of Labor State Ministers and those of a Labor senator when he was, conveniently, in opposition. They had no doubt that responsibility for emergency relief rested with the Commonwealth. Of course, they may have forgotten that the Commonwealth has made a contribution to emergency relief for some years. It makes a direct contribution now to some of the great non-government agencies. I recall that some years ago the Commonwealth took over responsibility for paying the pension and supporting payments for the first six months following family breakdown. By so doing, it relieved State treasuries of expenses that they had borne previously. But at that time, understanding that the States had needs in the emergency area, the Commonwealth sought no adjustment of payments between the States on the understanding that moneys so released would go to continuing emergency care.

What do we find today? The Commonwealth is unwilling to meet the bill and the States are unwilling to continue to pay what they have paid. We know what Senator Grimes's view was in opposition. Whether he was right or wrong, we are interested in whether he will honour his promises now that he is in government. It is very clear that the poor in my State in desperate circumstances, without food, shelter and accommodation, have now nowhere to turn. The voluntary agencies to which many of us give donations-many people in my State support them very generously-are simply running out of the capacity to respond. What are people to do? They go to the Department of Youth and Community Services and they are told that it is no longer the policy of the Labor Government in New South Wales to meet the emergency needs of the residents of that State.

I would be interested, when Labor senators respond in this debate, to learn whether, in the light of this crisis, they contend that the Federal Government should meet the need. There is a very important argument to be resolved between the two levels of government, but while it is being resolved there is no merit, no justification and no equity in the poor being left to bear the brunt of the situation. I want to know what honourable members opposite will say in this debate about the extra State charges-the rental charges, the electricity, the financial mismanagement and the transport charges-to which my colleague will refer later. I want to know what they want to see done about those things that are adding to the burden which the poor have to bear. I am amazed and upset that two Labor governments purporting to be champions of the poor are themselves the cause of this suffering and this crisis in my State of New South Wales. The people of New South Wales are asking: What is going on? Just how sincere is the commitment of these Labor governments to the very poorest in the community?

I would acknowledge immediately that this Government has in certain areas increased welfare payments and welfare benefits, and I applaud it for that. I hope that it is not going to trot those increases out as some justification for the crisis we have, because they have no bearing upon the crisis. The extra payments in the income security area will be welcomed by those who receive them. Some of that money will go to pay the increased State charges, to the New South Wales Government.

What we are on about at the moment is the public crisis in my State for the needy who have no government sources of emergency benefits remaining to them. We know what Senator Grimes's promise was. We know what his view was when he was the Opposition spokesman. When we Liberals were in government his view was that the responsibility rested in Canberra. We should be interested to know why it is that he may take a different view now that he has ceased to be a member of the Opposition and has become a Minister of the Crown.

The Labor Government of my State of New South Wales can take no pride at all in what has happened. As usual, when we read the words and past promises of the Premier of my State and look at what has happened, we get a picture of deceit. In 1982 the Premier of my State, the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Wran, said:
One thing the Government is not going to do-whether it's a time of financial stringency or not-we're not going to hurt the poorest people in the community.

That is a promise which Mr Wran found it possible to make in 1982. I refer honourable senators to a more extensive interview quoted by the Sydney Moring Herald on 1 March of that year in which he set out the ways in which his Government was going to preserve the rights of the disadvantaged. I repeat his words:
One thing the Government is not going to do . . . we're not going to hurt the poorest people in the community.

Yet, only three years later, the Wran Labor Government has slashed emergency relief, causing some of the poor to do without food and aggravating their problems in even being able to take advantage of health services and to get shelter, and depriving others of clothing and other assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful.

—It is shameful, as my colleague Senator Puplick says. What the Opposition is looking for, whether or not the difference of principle between governments is resolved, is some action-now, today-to relieve the situation in New South Wales. He wants some action now to help the people in need. As I said, the battling between macho Ministers is no excuse.

SPEECH.PARA: Poverty exists and runs deep in my State, and the need for emergency relief has been there for years and will continue to be there for years to come. It is clear that this need is not being met. It is not being met because money which was previously available to help the poor and needy has been withdrawn from them. That is what has brought on the crisis. It is not just a question of more money. Let no-one paint the issue in those kinds of terms. It is a question of trying to maintain the level of emergency relief which was there previously.

TALK.START.PARA: —More money in the right place.
—More money in the right place. If there is an issue between governments, let them resolve it off stage, without making the clients the victims of their fight.

SPEECH.PARA: What is needed today is that the whole high noon atmosphere, the whole high noon confrontation between macho Ministers-Labor Minister in New South Wales and Labor Minister in Canberra-be ended. We want relief now. We want the Smith Family to be able to help people who need help. We want the soup kitchens and those who are giving their help to be able to give it and not turn people away. We understand that community development and getting to the causes of poverty are an important part of a long term solution. But in the short term a crisis in New South Wales this week and last week was brought on by governments. Of course, we know that no Minister in the State Labor Government and no Minister in the Federal Labor Government will have to call upon these emergency services, insulated as they are behind their $80,000 salaries. They can afford to undertake their battles. They can afford to fight these arguments of constitutional arrangements. They can afford to determine who is and who is not responsible. They can afford to use the poor as hostages in this fight. They are quite secure. But we cannot afford so to do. We cannot afford to stand by. I do not determine how the argument should be resolved. I do not want to enter that fight. I do not want to say that the State is right or the Commonwealth is right. All I demand, on behalf of my State and on behalf of the poor, is that they sort it out, and that they sort it out now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government acknowledges that, for a change, the Opposition has raised a matter of real public importance, namely, the wellbeing of our poorest Australians. But I reject the accusation by Senator Peter Baume of failure to provide adequate emergency relief by this Government. Whatever is provided, of course, it will never be enough. There will always be the need for more. But how can Senator Peter Baume say it is inadequate when his Party promised only half the amount that Labor has proposed and has delivered? Of course, he carefully made sure that he did not come down on the side of one government or the other. That would have spoilt his argument. He refused to deal with the principle. He said that the matter needs fixing, but he came up with no solution whatsoever. He knows it would not be appropriate for the Commonwealth to do one thing in New South Wales and not in other States. It would probably be unconstitutional, anyway. I emphasise too, that there is not a confrontation between Ministers. Senator Grimes, as Minister for Community Services, has been publicly very gentle with New South Wales. I emphasise that in no way did Senator Peter Baume commit himself to saying whether Senator Grimes was right or wrong. He would not say whether the State or the Commonwealth was right. He, of course, did not want to enter the argument.

SPEECH.PARA: Many things about the matter of public importance that has been raised by the Opposition amaze me. The first is its timing. Why does Senator Peter Baume select the first sitting day after the responsible Minister, Senator Grimes, has left for overseas on government business? The issue has been around for some time. It has not suddenly arisen today. Yet the Opposition waits until the Minister is away. It is quite strange that it should do that. Perhaps it is because the matter finally got a mention in the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday and in an editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald today.
